name: Niels van der Linden
title: Amateur economist, VforVoluntary.com
article: Don't Buy Bitcoins

name: Avery Pennarun
title: Software engineer
article: Why bitcoin will fail
excerpt: See, a bitcoin rant is almost too over-the-top for me. Asking why I think bitcoin won't work is like asking why the sky isn't red. I mean, wait, you think it is red? You actually took that seriously? Oh boy. Where do I even start?

name: Peter Schiff
title: CEO, Euro Pacific Capital, Inc.
article: Peter Schiff Radio Show with Bitcoin
excerpt: What [bitcoins] lack is their own fundamental intrinsic value. You can’t do anything with a bitcoin, other than trade it for something you want. So, intrinsically, the bitcoin itself has no value. It only has value as a medium of exchange so long as people are willing to accept it.

name: Adrian Covert
title: Journalist
article: The Bitcoin Is Dying
excerpt: The lulz were abundant. But frankly, it’s time for you to go. Farewell.

name: Paul Krugman
title: Nobel Prize-winning Economist
article: Golden Cyberfetters
excerpt: So to the extent that the [Bitcoin] experiment tells us anything about monetary regimes, it reinforces the case against anything like a new gold standard – because it shows just how vulnerable such a standard would be to money-hoarding, deflation, and depression.

name: Michael Calore
title: Journalist
article: Wired, Tired, Expired for 2012: From Stellar to Suck
excerpt: Then came the malware, the black market, the legal ambiguities and The Man. Today, you can't even use it to buy Facebook stock

name: Tim Worstall
title: Journalist
article: So, That's the End of Bitcoin Then
excerpt: It’s difficult to see what the currency has going for it.

name: Patrik Korda
title: Amateur trader
article: Bitcoin Bubble 2.0
excerpt: Thus, we have an answer before us: bitcoins are fiduciary media, or more specifically token money. From a monetary standpoint, as devised and formulated by Ludwig von Mises, they are on a par with the stuff you find at Chuck E. Cheese's.

name: Heidi Moore
title: Finance and Economics Editor, The Guardian US
article: Confused about Bitcoin? It's 'the Harlem Shake of currency'
excerpt: Of course, in a rational world, none of that will be written, except perhaps as satire. Bitcoin's crash is less of a currency crisis than an opportune moment for internet wisecracks.

name: Robert McMillan
title: Journalist
article: Watch Wired Get Rich Quick With Our Sleek Bitcoin Miner
excerpt: But in the end, the answer was obvious. The world’s most popular digital currency really is nothing more than an abstraction. So we’re destroying the private key used by our Bitcon wallet.

name: Ian Bremmer
title: Founder and President, Eurasia Group
article: Strategist predicts end of Bitcoin
excerpt: "I would be very surprised if Bitcoin is still around in 10 years," said Bremmer, the founder and CEO of Eurasia Group, the world's largest risk consulting firm. He thinks that bigger players will enter the field and improve upon Bitcoin's weaknesses.

name: Kurt Eichenwald
title: Contributing editor, Vanity Fair
article: The Logic Problems That Will Eventually Pop the Bitcoin Bubble
excerpt: So, anyone out there buying Bitcoins at ridiculously inflated prices, please recognize the risk you are taking. You will likely lose everything.

name: David S. Evans
title: Chairman of the Global Economics Group
article: Bitcoin is a Remarkable Innovation, Here's Why It Will Fail
excerpt: I think there are two realistic directions the bitcoin ecosystem could go in. First, it could just implode and disappear if governments decide that virtual currencies cause too much harm and are too hard to regulate. Long-term investments in bitcoin would then go up in smoke. Second, it could continue as a virtual currency that is only used on the dark web with exchanges that are run by people willing to break the laws. The value of bitcoin would decline to whatever the illegal sector could support; regular investors wouldn’t be able to get their value from bitcoin unless they cashed it in with someone who wanted to do bad things.

name: Joseph Weisenthal
title: Executive Editor, Business Insider
article: Bitcoin Is A Joke
excerpt: Bitcoin? Nada. There's nothing keeping it being a thing. If people lose faith in it, it's over. Bitcoin is fiat currency in the most literal sense of the word.

name: Matthew O'Brien
title: Journalist
article: Bitcoin Is the Segway of Currency
excerpt: In other words, Bitcoin is a Ponzi scheme libertarians use to make money off each other—because gold wasn't enough of one for them.

name: Gary North
title: Economist
article: Bitcoins: The Second Biggest Ponzi Scheme in History
excerpt: Bitcoins will never achieve this. It is a mania going up. It will be a mania coming down. It will not increase the division of labor, because people will recognize it as having been a Ponzi scheme, and they will not again buy it. They will not use it in exchange. Companies will not sell goods and services based on Bitcoins. Bitcoins have to have stable purchasing power if they are to serve as money, and they will never, ever achieve stable purchasing power.

name: Matthew Yglesias
title: Executive Editor, Vox
article: Why I Haven't Changed My Mind About Bitcoin
excerpt: My primary interest in Bitcoin is that I think it's a great platform for making jokes.

name: Mark T. Williams
title: Finance Professor, Boston University
article: Beware of Bitcoin
excerpt: Once sellers outnumber buyers, prices will eventually drop below $10, erasing all gains. This price collapse will occur by the first half of 2014.

name: Alex Payne
title: Developer and Angel Investor
article: Bitcoin, Magical Thinking, and Political Ideology
excerpt: Bitcoin represents more of the same short-sighted hypercapitalism that got us into this mess, minus the accountability.

name: Charlie Stross
title: Author
article: Why I want Bitcoin to die in a fire
excerpt: TL:DR; the current banking industry and late-period capitalism may suck, but replacing it with Bitcoin would be like swapping out a hangnail for Fournier's gangrene.

name: Edward Hadas
title: Economics Editor, Reuters
article: Bitcoin Mania Heads Into the Endgame
excerpt: The electronic pseudocurrency has had a good run. Ideologues, speculators and scammers enjoyed the fun while it lasted. But now that the authorities are taking notice, the price has much further to fall.

name: Brad DeLong
title: Professor of Economics, U.C. Berkeley
article: Watching Bitcoin, Dogecoin, Etc...
excerpt: You can either work doing something useful, or you can set up a botnet to mine BitCoins, or you can fork the code behind BitCoin and set up your own slightly-tweaked virtual cryptographic money network. Setting up a new, alternative network is really cheap. Thus unless BitCoin going can somehow successfully differentiate itself from the latecomers who are about to emerge, the money supply of BitCoin-like things is infinite because the cost of production of them is infinitesimal.

name: Lisa Kramer
title: "Serious Economist"
article: Bursting the bitcoin bubble
excerpt: As a Serious Economist, I had been happily ignoring the recent bitcoin frenzy, safe in the smug knowledge shared by all Serious Economists that the surge in bitcoin value is a bubble that will soon pop.

name: Jamie Dimon
title: President & CEO, JPMorgan Chase
article: Dimon Disses Bitcoin, and Bitcoiners Diss Back
excerpt: "It’s a terrible store of value," Mr. Dimon said in an interview with CNBC. "It could be replicated over and over."

name: Paul Singer
title: CEO, Elliott Management Corporation
article: Paul Singer: Bitcoin over gold? Are you crazy?!
excerpt: There is no more reason to believe that bitcoin will stand the test of time than that governments will protect the value of government-created money, although bitcoin is newer and we always look at babies with hope.

name: Robert J. Shiller
title: Nobel Prize-winning Economist
article: In Search of a Stable Electronic Currency
excerpt: The Bitcoin phenomenon seems to fit the basic definition of a speculative bubble — that is, a special kind of fad, a mania for holding an asset in expectation of its appreciation.

name: Mark Cuban
title: TV Actor, Shark Tank
article: Mark Cuban says Cyber Dust app keeps you in control
excerpt: I think as an encryption technology, [Bitcoin’s] great. I think as a transport mechanism, accounting of a transport mechanism, that it's unique and has a great opportunity in the future. I think it has no shot as a long term digital currency. [Would you buy any?] Yeah, I mean I'd look at it, but more as fun, you know? It's almost like buying and selling baseball cards, but there's definitely risk involved if you're looking at it to be a long term currency.

name: Nouriel Roubini
title: Professor of Economics, New York University

name: Warren Buffett
title: Chairman & CEO, Berkshire Hathaway
article: Buffett: ‘Stay Away’ From Bitcoin
excerpt: "Stay away from it," he said, according to a transcript. "It’s a mirage basically."

name: Anthony Watson & Halsey Minor
title: CEO and Founder & Chairman, Uphold (formerly Bitreserve), respectively
article: This bitcoin startup is changing its name and moving away from bitcoin
excerpt:
Watson sounds even more negative on bitcoin. “I’ll be surprised if bitcoin is here in five years,” he has told Fortune. “The value of bitcoin isn’t the currency, but the technology. I think once the world becomes more accustomed and attuned to the platform of bitcoin, the noise will go away, and the currency will go away too.
[…]
Minor, too, predicts that bitcoin as a currency “will get destroyed.” He likens the coin’s current market cap—about $3.7 billion—to “an accounting mistake or rounding error that Bank of America makes.”

name: Mike Hearn
title: Lead Platform Engineer, R3CV
article: The resolution of the Bitcoin experiment
excerpt: But despite knowing that Bitcoin could fail all along, the now inescapable conclusion that it has failed still saddens me greatly. The fundamentals are broken and whatever happens to the price in the short term, the long term trend should probably be downwards. I will no longer be taking part in Bitcoin development and have sold all my coins.

name: Vivek Wadhwa
title: Contributor, The Washington Post; Tryhard
article: R.I.P., Bitcoin. It’s time to move on.
excerpt: Bitcoin did have great potential, but it is damaged beyond repair. A replacement is badly needed.

name: Jeremy Allaire
title: CEO, Circle
article: Circle CEO Allaire: It’s Highly Unlikely We’ll Be Using Bitcoin in 5 or 10 Years
excerpt: “Our view is that we’re still in the really early stages of the technology and its development,” said Allaire. “It’s highly unlikely that any of us will be using Bitcoin in five or ten years. In the same way that — how many of us use NCSA Mosaic or Netscape Navigator?”

name: Timothy B. Lee
title: Senior correspondent, technology and economics, Lead writer for "New Money", Vox Media
article: Bitcoin was supposed to change the world. What happened?
excerpt: What went wrong? The Bitcoin community has been hampered by a dysfunctional culture that has grown increasingly hostile toward experimentation. That has made it difficult for the Bitcoin network to keep up with changing market demands...Bitcoin's larger problem may be that it just doesn’t solve any problems normal people have.

name: Dan McCrum
title: Editor, Financial Times
article: Bitcoin passes $1,000 but only number that matters is zero
excerpt: As a phenomenon bitcoin has all the attributes of a pyramid scheme, requiring a constant influx of converts to push up the price, based on the promise of its use by future converts. So the ultimate value for bitcoin will be the same as all pyramid schemes: zero.

name: Raoul Pal
title: Macro Strategist, GMI
article: Bitcoin Is Mania, Not a Store of Value… I Sold-Out Last Week
excerpt: Bitcoin was supposed to be a store of value, you couldn’t mess with the formula… and now they are talking about a ‘hard fork’ changing it? Even if they don’t change the formula, the fact that they could? That’s enough to say it’s not a long-term store of value.

name: Howard Marks
title: Co-chairman, Oaktree Capital
article: Billionaire investor Marks, who called the dotcom bubble, says bitcoin is a 'pyramid scheme'
excerpt: In my view, digital currencies are nothing but an unfounded fad (or perhaps even a pyramid scheme), based on a willingness to ascribe value to something that has little or none beyond what people will pay for it.

name: Kenneth Rogoff
title: Professor of Economics and Public Policy, Harvard University; Former Chief Economist, IMF
article: Bitcoin's price bubble will burst under government pressure
excerpt: My best guess is that in the long run, the technology will thrive, but that the price of bitcoin will collapse.

name: Al-Waleed Bin Talal bin Abdulaziz al Saud
title: Citigroup shareholder
article: Prince Alwaleed says bitcoin will implode: 'Enron in the making'
excerpt: I just don't believe in this bitcoin thing. I think it's just going to implode one day. I think this is Enron in the making.

name: Bill Harris
title: Founder & CEO, Personal Capital; Former CEO of PayPal and Intuit
article: Bitcoin is the greatest scam in history
excerpt: In my opinion, [Bitcoin’s] a colossal pump-and-dump scheme, the likes of which the world has never seen.

name: Robert C. Merton
title: Nobel Prize-winning Economist; Failed and bailed out co-founder, Long-Term Capital Management
article: Why a Nobel laureate in economics thinks bitcoin is toast
excerpt: The problem with bitcoin at the moment, despite Ohio, is just what its champions decry: It is not a government-controlled currency. And therefore, asks Merton, who is responsible for the value of our currency if tomorrow morning all the bitcoin screens go dark?

name: Steven Mnuchin
title: United States Secretary of the Treasury
excerpt: I won't be talking about Bitcoin in 10 years, I can assure you that. […] I would bet in even 5 or 6 years I'm no longer talking about Bitcoin as Treasury Secretary. […] I can assure you I will personally not be loaded up on Bitcoin.

name: Tendayi Kapfidze
title: Chief Economist, LendingTree
article: Bitcoin is a pyramid scheme, economist says
excerpt:
“It’s a pyramid scheme,” LendingTree Chief Economist Tendayi Kapfidze tells Yahoo Finance. “You only make money based on people who enter after you. It has no real utility in the world.

“They’ve been trying to create a utility for it for ten years now. It’s a solution in search of a problem and it still hasn’t found a problem to solve.”
